#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Bengkulu
#Text=Bengkulu is the capital of Bengkulu province , which is named after the city , on the island of Sumatra , Indonesia .
#Text=With a population of 329,000 ( latest estimate for 2014 ) , Bengkulu is the largest city of Bengkulu province .
#Text=It was founded by the British as their main source of pepper for almost two hundred years , before being exchanged for Malacca in 1824 .
#Text=The city offers slow-paced and quiet coastal life - locals hang out on the beach in the late afternoon buying freshly caught fish and waiting for the sun to set .
#Text=History
#Text=Several small chiefdoms ruled what is nowadays the Bengkulu area .
#Text=These chiefdoms were under the loose suzerainty of the Inderapura Sultanate from southern West Sumatra .

#Text=They did n’t flourish as much as the settlements in the eastern part of Sumatra that enjoyed the bustling traffic of Malacca Strait ; they were far from major population centres , lacked natural harbours , and were swarmed with diseases .
#Text=Inderapura became a vassal of the Banten Sultanate after its ruler married the daughter of Inderapura ’s sultan circa 1560 .
#Text=In 1682 , the Dutch attacked Banten and expelled all other Europeans including the British from that town .
#Text=The British thereupon signed a treaty with some chiefs , so as to maintain a presence in Sumatra .

#Text=After a failed attempt by Banten-Dutch forces to knock the British out , the British established a trading post under the East Indian Company , named the area Bencoolen , and secured a safe anchorage spot for their ships .
#Text=Their first fort ( Fort York ) did n’t last very long , leading them to built Fort Marlborough in 1714 , which still robustly stands today .

#Text=This trading post brought the British only trouble , as it was never profitable , quarrels constantly broke out with the locals , and the local climate was deemed highly unpleasant ; yet in spite of all of this , the British remained for another century .
#Text=In 1807 , a rebellion broke out to end the rule of Thomas Parr , the Resident of Bencoolen at that time .
#Text=He was killed and decapitated in his home during the uprising .
#Text=Founder of modern Singapore , Thomas Stamford Raffles landed in Bencoolen on 19 March 1818 to assume the rule of the colony ’s Governor General .
#Text=He managed to abolish slavery , sent in convict labourers from India , and limited cockfighting and similar games among locals .
#Text=During his time , the tug-of-war between the British and the Dutch concerning the archipelago once again took place .
#Text=Somehow it was resolved in the Anglo-Dutch Treaty in 1824 , in which British Bencoolen was ceded in exchange for Dutch Malacca .
#Text=Bencoolen ( which became Bengkoelen and Bengkulu later ) remained part of the Dutch East Indies until the Japanese occupation in World War II .
#Text=During Sukarno 's imprisonment by the Dutch in the early 1930s , the future first president of Indonesia lived briefly in Bengkulu where he met his wife , Fatmawati .
#Text=After independence , the city became part of Sumatra Province , then South Sumatra Province , and finally was made capital of the newly-formed Bengkulu Province .
#Text=Bengkulu lies near the Sunda Fault and is prone to earthquakes and tsunamis .
#Text=In June 2000 , an earthquake killed at least 100 people .
#Text=A series of earthquakes struck Bengkulu later during September 2007 , killing 13 people .
#Text=A recent report predicts that Bengkulu is at risk of inundation over the next few decades from undersea earthquakes predicted along the coast of Sumatra .
#Text=Talk
#Text=Indonesian is widely used in the city for official business , education , commerce , and service purposes .
#Text=Locals also speak Bengkulunese Malay , lingua franca of the province , especially when conversing among themselves .
#Text=Both are mutually intelligible , with little adaptation required
#Text=Foreign languages are rarely heard in the city .
#Text=Basic Indonesian knowledge helps a lot during your stay here .
#Text=Youths should be able to hold conversation in basic English , although most of them will be quite shy about engaging in conversation in a foreign tongue .
#Text=Despite that , locals are very happy to help and try their best .
#Text=By plane
#Text=Fatmawati Soekarno Airport ( BKS ) .
#Text=Serves Bengkulu , the city and the province .

#Text=As of 2016 , there are eight , daily direct flights from Jakarta ( both Soekarno-Hatta International Airport and Halim Perdanakusuma Airport in East Jakarta ) , as well as direct flights from Palembang , Batam , and Bandar Lampung .
#Text=The airport also connects the city to several small towns inland .
#Text=There is no direct international flight to Bengkulu , and domestic flights are few and tend to be rather expensive .
#Text=The airport itself consists of two terminals , one is used for high-ranking government service .
#Text=You can find airlines ticket counters and ATM gallery on the landside of two-storey main terminal , as well as restaurant , gift shop , and lounge on the airside .
#Text=By bus
#Text=Siliwangi Antar Nusa ( SAN ) , ☏ +62214705502 .
#Text=SAN buses to Bengkulu would take Trans-Sumatran Highway East Route that passes through towns .
#Text=In turn , the road is in better condition and safer to travel .
#Text=Jakarta-Bengkulu Rp350.000 ( 25 hours ) , Padang-Bengkulu Rp200.000 ( 12 hours ) .
#Text=Putra Rafflesia , ☏ +62214892717 .

#Text=Putra Rafflesia buses to Bengkulu takes Trans-Sumatera West Route which cuts the travel time but the road is not as good as its eastern counterpart as it passes some jungles and hills ( Bukit Barisan Selatan National Park ) .
#Text=Jakarta-Bengkulu Rp.340.000 ( 22 hours ) , Pekanbaru-Bengkulu Rp220.000 .
#Text=Jakarta-Bengkulu ( Rp280.000 ) .
#Text=There are also several van travel services that ply the route between Padang and Palembang toward Bengkulu .

#Text=Journey from/to Padang may pass Muara Bungo and Sarolangun in Jambi province ( Trans-Sumatran Highway East Route ) or the coastal road that go through Mukomuko and Painan ( Trans-Sumatran Highway West Route ) .
#Text=The latter offers less winding roads , although at some spots , there are potholes and damaged section due to its proximity to the beach .
#Text=You should ask the travel counter before booking any ticket .
#Text=By minivan
#Text=Minivan ( angkot ) acts as the city 's sole public transport system .

#Text=Riding the minivan will also give you insight into the daily life in the city , since its service covers most of Bengkulu , including traditional markets , business districts , and residential areas .
#Text=There are neither fixed timetables nor proper stops .
#Text=You can hail and alight from anywhere along the streets .
#Text=State your destination before you board and pay when you alight .
#Text=As of 2016 , it costs Rp4.000 per trip regardless of distance .
#Text=Operating hour is 06AM-06PM .
#Text=The drivers usually wait for their van to be filled , which may prolong your waiting time .
#Text=They are not likely to speak English , so you 'll need basic knowledge of Indonesian to ask for information or anything else .
#Text=Words you need to know are " kiri " ( kee-ree ) or " minggir " ( meeng-gear ) which indicates you want to alight .
#Text=The minivan is colour- and alphabet-coded , based on which line it 's operated in .
#Text=Each alphabet actually has suffix to indicate certain route it takes , but in practice only Green and Red minivan follow the convention .
#Text=Yellow minivan/A line ( angkot kuning ) .
#Text=Green minivan/B line ( angkot hijau ) .
#Text=Red minivan/C line ( angkot merah ) .
#Text=Blue minivan/D line ( angkot biru ) .
#Text=White minivan/E line ( angkot putih ) .
